Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery open vessel, possibly a krater; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration in two friezes separated by thin line: above, goat (only head and one foreleg remaining); below, possibly a bull (head, rump, and hindlegs missing; with added red on belly), to left.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Outer surface is very worn. The sherd is mentioned by Clairmont in Berytus, XI, 1955, p. 117, no. 175, probably the only piece from Naukratis in his list of Greek pottery from the Near East.
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels III / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 21, pl. 28, no. 6)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1044)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
